page.title: History of slavery in New Jersey

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{NJhistory}}
{{Slavery}}
'''Slavery in New Jersey''' began in the early 17th century, when Dutch colonists imported African slaves for labor to develop their colony of [[New Netherland]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.rutgersuniversitypress.org/scarlet-and-black/9780813591520|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=|first=|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=9780813591520|editor-last=Fuentes|editor-first=Marisa|location=New Brunswick, NJ|pages=|editor-last2=White|editor-first2=Deborah Gray}}</ref>{{Rp|44}} After [[England]] took control the colony in 1664, its colonists continued the [[Atlantic slave trade|importation of slaves from Africa]]. They also imported "seasoned" slaves from their colonies in the [[West Indies]] and enslaved [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] from the [[Carolinas]].
Most [[Dutch American|Dutch]] and English immigrants entered the colony as [[indentured servant]]s, who worked for a fixed number of years to repay their passage. As conditions in England improved and the number of indentured laborers declined, New Jersey's colonists imported more [[Africans]] for needed labor. To promote increasing the number of laborers and settlers in order to develop the colony, the colonial government awarded settlers [[headrights]] of {{convert|60|acre|ha}} of land for each person transported to the colony. In 1704, after [[East Jersey]] and [[West Jersey]] unified, the [[Province of New Jersey]] passed a slave code prohibiting slaves and free blacks from owning property, further restricting African Americans in the state.<ref name=":2" />{{Rp|44}}
During the [[American Revolution]], enslaved African Americans fought on each side. The British Crown promised freedom to slaves who would leave their rebel masters and fight for the British. The number of blacks in Manhattan increased to 10,000, as thousands of slaves escaped to the British for the promise of freedom. The British refused to return former slaves to the Americans and they evacuated many Black Loyalists together with their troops and other Loyalists; they resettled more than 3,000 freedmen in their colony of Nova Scotia. Others were transported to England and the West Indies.
Bergen County developed as the largest slaveholding county in the state,<ref>[http://sites.bergen.org/ourstory/Resources/slave&war/sl_secondary.htm "Bergen County Slavery"], Bergen County, accessed 13 July 2012</ref> in part because many slaves were used as laborers in its ports and cities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kennedy|first=Michael V.|date=2003-01-01|title=THE HIDDEN ECONOMY OF SLAVERY: COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL HIRING IN PENNSYLVANIA, NEW JERSEY AND DELAWARE, 1728-1800|url=https://doaj.org/|journal=Essays in Economic and Business History|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|issn=0896-226X}}</ref> After the Revolutionary War, many northern states rapidly passed laws to abolish slavery, but New Jersey did not abolish it until 1804, and then in a process of gradual emancipation similar to that of New York. But, in New Jersey, some slaves were held as late as 1865. (In New York, they were all freed by 1827.) The law made African Americans free at birth, but it required children (born to slave mothers), to serve lengthy [[apprenticeship]]s as a type of [[indentured servant]] until early adulthood for the masters of their slave mothers. New Jersey was the last of the [[Union (American Civil War)|Northern]] states to abolish slavery completely. The last 16 slaves in New Jersey were freed in 1865 by the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Thirteenth Amendment]].<ref name="autogenerated2007">[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/social_issues/jan-june07/divided_01-25.html "Interview: James Oliver Horton: Exhibit Reveals History of Slavery in New York City"], PBS Newshour, 25 January 2007, accessed 11 February 2012</ref>
The [[Underground Railroad]] had several [[List of Underground Railroad sites|routes]] crossing the state,<ref>{{cite web | title = "Steal Away, Steal Away ..." A Guide to the Underground Railroad in New Jersey | publisher = New Jersey Historical Commission | date = | url = http://slic.njstatelib.org/slic_files/digidocs/h673/h6732002.pdf | accessdate = 2014-04-15 | quote = | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130823115712/http://slic.njstatelib.org/slic_files/digidocs/h673/h6732002.pdf | archivedate = 2013-08-23 | df = }}</ref> four of which ended in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]], where fugitive slaves could cross the [[North River (Hudson River)|Hudson River]].<ref name="Karnoutsos">{{cite web | last = Karnoutsos | first = Carmela | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Underground Railroad | work = Jersey City Past and Present | publisher = New Jersey City University | date = | url = http://www.njcu.edu/programs/jchistory/Pages/U_Pages/Underground_Railroad.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2011-03-27 | quote = }}</ref> New Brunswick, 'Hub City', was a main location where runaways would travel during the days of the Underground Railroad.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=Fuentes,|first=Marisa J,|last2=White|first2=Deborah Gray|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New Brunswick|pages=93}}</ref> During the [[American Civil War]], African Americans served in several all-black Union Army regiments from New Jersey.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Rizzo | first = Nina | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Historian highlights service of NJ's black Civil War troops | newspaper = Asbury Park Press | pages = | year = | date = February 28, 2011 | url = http://www.app.com/article/20110227/NJNEWS/102270367/Historian-highlights-service-NJ-s-black-Civil-War-troops | accessdate = 2011-03-31 |quote = | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref>
In 2008, the legislature of New Jersey passed a resolution of official apology for slavery, becoming the third state to do so.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/US/01/07/nj.slavery.bill/|title=New Jersey officially apologizes for slavery - CNN.com|website=www.cnn.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-04}}</ref> Rutgers, the State University moved to rectify its past wrongs and connections to slavery during its 250th anniversary celebration in 2016.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=Fuentes|first=Marisa|last2=White|first2=Deborah Grey|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New Brunswick|pages=44}}</ref> [[Princeton University]], the oldest college in the state of New Jersey, released the findings of its [https://slavery.princeton.edu/ Princeton & Slavery Project] in 2017.<ref name="Schuessler">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/arts/princeton-digs-deep-into-its-fraught-racial-history.html?action=click&contentCollection=Arts&module=RelatedCoverage&region=EndOfArticle&pgtype=article&_r=0|title=Princeton Digs Deep Into Its Fraught Racial History|last=Schuessler|first=Jennifer|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en}}</ref>
==Colonial period== The [[Dutch West India Company]] introduced slavery in 1625 with the importation of eleven black slaves to [[New Amsterdam]], capital of the nascent province of [[New Netherland]]. They worked as farmers, [[fur traders]], and builders.<ref name = "branchandroot">{{Cite journal | last = Hodges | first = Russel Graham | author-link = | last2 =| first2 =| author2-link = | title = Root and Branch: African Americans in New York and East Jersey, 1613-1863 | place = Chapel Hill, North Carolina | publisher = University of North Carolina Press | year = 1999 | volume =| edition =| url =| doi =| id = | isbn =| quote = | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref> It later expanded across the [[North River (Hudson River)]] to [[Pavonia, New Netherland|Pavonia]] and [[Communipaw]], eventually becoming [[Bergen, New Netherland|Bergen]], where slaves worked the company [[plantation]].<ref name = "branchandroot"/> Settlers to the area later held slaves privately, often using them as domestic servants and laborers.<ref name="Karnoutsos"/><ref name="shakir"/> Although enslaved, the Africans had a few basic rights and families were usually kept intact. They were admitted to the [[Dutch Reformed Church]] and married by its ministers, who also baptized their children. While enslaved Africans could be admitted to the Church, the church itself did not prohibit their enslavement. In fact, the Church did not even find that enslavement sinful.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Ragged Road to Abolition: Slavery and Freedom in New Jersey, 1775-1865|last=Gigantino|first=James|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=12, 236–237}}</ref> Slaves could testify in court, sign legal documents, and bring civil actions against whites. Some were permitted to work after hours, when they earned wages equal to those paid to white workers. When the colony fell, the company freed all its slaves, establishing early on a nucleus of [[free negro]]s.<ref name = "branchandroot"/><ref>{{Cite book | last = Switala | first = William J | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Underground Railroad in New York and New Jersey | place = | publisher = Stackpole Books | year = 2006 | volume = | edition = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CKjSCjMKhmYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Underground+railroad+in+New+Jersey+and+New+York#v=onepage&q&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8117-3258-1 | quote = | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref>
English traders continued to import African slaves after they took over the colony from the Dutch in 1664 and established a proprietorship. Eager to attract more settlers and laborers to develop the colony, the proprietorship encouraged the importation of slaves for labor by offering settlers [[headright]]s, an award of allocations of land based on the number of workers, slaves or indentured servants, imported to the colony. The first African slaves to appear in English records were owned by Colonel [[Lewis Morris (governor)|Lewis Morris]] in [[Shrewsbury, New Jersey|Shrewsbury]].<ref name="shakir">{{cite news |first=Nancy |last=Shakir |url=http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_jersey.htm |title=Slavery in New Jersey |accessdate=2008-10-22 |quote= |publisher=[[Slaveryinamerica]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20031017072606/http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_jersey.htm |archivedate=2003-10-17 |df= }}</ref> In an early attempt to encourage European settlement, the New Jersey legislature enacted a prohibitive tariff against imported slaves to encourage European indentured servitude.<ref name="SimeonRoyal"> {{Cite book | last = Moss | first = Simeon F. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = The Persistence of Slavery and Involuntary Servitude in a Free State (1685-1866) | place = | publisher = The Journal of Negro History | year = July 1950 | volume = Vol. 35, No. 3 (Jul., 1950) | edition = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gO4oHqpJ6NIC&pg=PA190&lpg=PA190&dq=The+Persistence+of+Slavery+and+Involuntary+Servitude+in+a+Free+State#v=onepage&q=The%20Persistence%20of%20Slavery%20and%20Involuntary%20Servitude%20in%20a%20Free%20State&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 9780813532677 | quote = | page=294 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> When this act expired in 1721, however, the British Government and New Jersey's royal governor, countered attempts to renew it. The slave trade was a royal monopoly and had become a lucrative enterprise.<ref name="SimeonRoyal"/>
The liberties of the enslaved peoples of New Jersey were formally curtailed under a law passed in 1704, a so-called 'slave code'. This code prohibited the owning of property for not only slaves, but also free African Americans as well. In addition, it made certain actions illegal for African Americans, like staying out past curfew, that were not illegal for European Americans.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ragged Road to Abolition|last=Gigantino|first=James|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=14}}</ref>
[[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]] was a center for the importation of slaves, its ferry docks on the [[Delaware River]] across from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] acting as auction sites for the plantations in the [[Delaware Valley]], of which [[Pomona Hall]] was one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://historiccamdencounty.com/ccnews136.shtml|title=Slave Ships on the Delaware: A Video Documentary|website=Historiccamdencounty.com|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref>
In 2016 [[Rutgers University]] published a report ''Scarlet and Black'' recording the university's relationship with slavery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/education/2016/11/rutgers_slavery_racism_report.html|title=Rutgers confronts its ties to slavery in groundbreaking report|website=Nj.com|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref> In 2017 [[Princeton University]] made public the findings of the [https://slavery.princeton.edu Princeton & Slavery Project], which is ongoing.<ref name="Schuessler"/>
==Post-American Revolution== African-American slaves fought on both sides in the War for Independence. The British Crown promised slaves freedom for leaving their rebel masters to join their cause. The number of blacks in New York rose to 10,000 as slaves escaped there from both northern and southern masters after the British occupied the city. The British kept their promise and evacuated thousands of [[freedmen]] from New York, resettling 3,500 [[Black Loyalists]] in its colony of Nova Scotia and others in the Caribbean islands.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_jersey.htm Nancy Shakir, "Slavery in New Jersey"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20031017072606/http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_jersey.htm |date=2003-10-17 }}, Slavery in America, Accessed 24 January 2007</ref> [[Colonel Tye]], also known as Titus Cornelius (c. 1753–1780),<ref name="Colonel Tye">[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part2/2p52.html "Colonel Tye"], ''Africans in America'', PBS</ref><ref name="books.google.co.th">[https://books.google.com/books?id=arI0HSFXwLkC&pg=PA420&lpg=PA420&dq=colonel+tye&source=bl&ots=HOeY5ga053&sig=t6wbrY5bWDZMQ6ESpUnUJjyFNR0&hl=th&ei=mi6eScL8NtK6kAWogO3GCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result Jonathan D. Sutherland, ''African Americans at War''], ABC-CLIO, 2003, accessed 4 May 2010</ref> was a slave of [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]] descent who achieved notability during the war by his leadership and fighting skills, and was one of the most effective [[guerrilla]] leaders opposing the American rebel forces in [[Central Jersey]].<ref name="Colonel Tye"/><ref name="books.google.co.th"/>
Following the Revolutionary War in the 1780s, New Jersey initially resisted the urge to free slaves due to a desire to re-build their devastated economy.<ref name=":2" />{{Rp|47}} According to the American historian Giles Wright, by 1790 New Jersey's enslaved population numbered approximately 14,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://slic.njstatelib.org/slic_files/imported/NJ_Information/Digital_Collections/Afro-Americans/AFAMC.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616164203/http://slic.njstatelib.org/slic_files/imported/NJ_Information/Digital_Collections/Afro-Americans/AFAMC.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-16 |df= }}</ref> They were virtually all of African descent.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070423155735/http://www.northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk5JmZnYmVsN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk2ODc3MDcz Lawrence Aaron, "Confronting New Jersey's slave past"], ''Bergen Record'', 10 February 2006. Accessed 24 January 2007.</ref> The 1790 federal census, however, recorded 11,423 slaves, 6.2 percent of the total population of 184,139.<ref>[http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/histcensus/php/state.php Historical Census Browser, 1790 census] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823030234/http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/histcensus/php/state.php |date=2007-08-23 }}. Accessed 28 December 2007</ref> In the decades before the Revolution, slaves were numerous near [[Perth Amboy]], a major point of entry, and in the eastern counties. Slaves were generally used for agricultural labor, but they also filled skilled artisan jobs in shipyards and industry in coastal cities.
==Abolition of slavery== Following the Revolutionary War, New Jersey banned the importation of slaves in 1788, but at the same time forbade free blacks from elsewhere from settling in the state.<ref name="slavenorth.com">[http://www.slavenorth.com/newjersey.htm Slavery in the North], Accessed 28 December 2007</ref> In the first two decades after the war, many northern states rapidly abolished slavery, and some slaveholders independently manumitted their slaves. Some people of color left the areas where they had been enslaved and moved to more frontier areas. Since slaves were widely used in agriculture, as well as the ports, the [[New Jersey state legislature]] was the last in the North to abolish slavery, passing a law in 1804 for its gradual abolition.<ref>[http://njlegallib.rutgers.edu/slavery/acts/A78.html "An Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery"] (15 February 1804), electronically transcribed text of act of the New Jersey State Legislature published by the New Jersey Digital Legal Library (hosted by Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey). Accessed 24 January 2007.</ref> The 1804 statute and subsequent laws freed children born after the law was passed. African Americans born to slave mothers after July 4, 1804 had to serve lengthy [[apprenticeship]]s to the owners of their mothers. Women were freed at 21, but men were not emancipated until the age of 25.<ref>[http://www.slavenorth.com/newjersey.htm Douglas Harper, "Slavery in New Jersey"], Slavery in the North website, 2003, accessed 13 July 2012</ref> Slaves who had been born before these laws were passed were considered, after 1846, as [[indentured servants]] who were "apprenticed for life."<ref name="Abolish">[http://njlegallib.rutgers.edu/slavery/acts/A98.html "An Act to Abolish Slavery"] (18 April 1846), electronically transcribed text of act of the New Jersey State Legislature published by the New Jersey Digital Legal Library (hosted by Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey).Accessed 21 February 2012.</ref>
Although at first New Jersey allowed [[free people of color]] to vote, the legislature disfranchised them in 1807, an exclusion that lasted until 1875. By 1830 two-thirds of the slaves remaining in the North were held by masters in New Jersey, as New York had freed the last of its slaves in 1827 under gradual abolition. It was not until 1846 that New Jersey abolished slavery, but it qualified it by redefining former slaves as apprentices who were "apprenticed for life" to their masters.<ref name="slavenorth.com"/><ref name="Abolish"/> Slavery did not truly end in the state until it was ended nationally in 1865 after the [[American Civil War]] and passage of the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Thirteenth Amendment]] to the US Constitution.
According to James Gigantino, during the early nineteenth century in New Jersey, there were more female than male slaves. After the passage of the Act of Gradual Abolition in New Jersey in 1804, a greater number of advertisements in the state for the full-title sale of female slaves of child-bearing age were published.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=The Ragged Road to Abolition|last=Gigantino|first=James J. II.|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=2014|isbn=9780812290226|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=134}}</ref> Female slaves and their reproductive capabilities were highly valuable because their children would be born as slaves for a term, even after the 1804 Act of Gradual Abolition. However, domestic skills and labor also affected the value and marketability of female slaves. By 1830, African Americans made up 6% of the total population of New Jersey. The city of New Brunswick had a large African American Population at an around 11%. This added one of the reasons why New Brunswick was a favorable location for runaways, but it also made the city into a popular site for slave hunters, who wished to enforce The Fugitive Slave Laws of 1850.<ref name=":01">{{Cite book|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=Fuentes|first=Marisa J.|last2=White|first2=Deborah Grey|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New Brunswick|pages=94}}</ref> In more urban areas of the state, like New Brunswick, NJ, there were a greater number of slave sale advertisements for female slaves prior to and post-passage of the 1804 Act of Gradual Abolition. This was because female slaves were more highly favored for domestic work, which was more prominent in urban spaces like New Brunswick. Enslaved women, however, were not confined to this work, and also performed manual labor across the state of New Jersey.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1 January 2007|title=In Pressing Need of Cash: Gender, Skill, and Family Persistence in the Domestic Slave Trade|jstor=i20064147|journal=Journal of African American History|volume=92| issue = 1|pages=30}}</ref>
Yet the Gradual Abolition Act of 1804 did not guarantee that a slave born after 1804 would gain their freedom. Slaveholders would regularly sell those slaves down south to states like Louisiana before the slaves reached manumission age, so they could make money off of them.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=Fuentes|first=Marisa J.|last2=White|first2=Deborah Gray|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New Brunswick|pages=103}}</ref> By the 1830s, slavery was on the decline in New Jersey.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Scarlet and Black: Slavery and Dispossession in Rutgers History|last=Fuentes|first=Marisa J.|last2=White|first2=Deborah Gray|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New Brunswick|pages=105}}</ref>
Communities of [[free negro]]s and [[freedmen]] formed at Dunkerhook in [[Paramus, New Jersey|Paramus]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lutins.org/dunkerh.html|title=Dunkerhook: Slave Community?|first=allen|last=lutins|website=Lutins.org|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref><ref>[http://www.preservationnj.org/site/ExpEng/index.php?/ten_most_11/index_detail/Zabriskie_Tenant_House] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213091604/http://www.preservationnj.org/site/ExpEng/index.php?%2Ften_most_11%2Findex_detail%2FZabriskie_Tenant_House|date=2013-12-13}}</ref> and at the New York state line at Skunk Hollow, also called The Mountain. A founding African-American settler bought land there in 1806, and later bought more. Other families joined him, and the community continued into the twentieth century.<ref>[http://palisadesny.com/history/skunk-hollow-history-19th-century-community-free-a/ Kathleen Sykes, "Skunk Hollow: History of a 19th Century Community of Free African-Americans"], ''The Palisades Newsletter'' (NY), Mar 2006 - Issue 192</ref> According to the historian David S. Cohen in ''The Ramapo Mountain People'' (1974), free people of color migrated from Manhattan into other parts of the frontier of northeastern New Jersey, where some intermarried and became ancestors of the [[Ramapo Mountain Indians]].<ref name="Cohen">Cohen, David Steven (1974), ''The Ramapo Mountain People'', New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, pp. 74, 197, {{ISBN|978-0-8135-1195-5}}</ref> (Cohen's findings have been disputed by some scholars, including Albert J. Catalano.<ref name="Catalano">{{cite news|last=Catalano |first=Albert J. |last2=Plache |first2=Matthew J. |date=April 30, 2006 |title=Opinion: The case for Ramapough tribal status |publisher=North Jersey Media Group |url=http://www.bergen.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk0MDYmZmdiZWw3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTY5MjY1MTUmeXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkxNA== |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060521135748/http://www.bergen.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk0MDYmZmdiZWw3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTY5MjY1MTUmeXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkxNA%3D%3D |archivedate=May 21, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>)
Accoriding to James J Gigantino, at the University of Arkansas, the efforts of New Jersey to legally abolish slavery during the years prior to the Civil War took a long period of time to officially abolish the practice, claiming that one in ten slaves remained that way for life. Many slaveholders sold their slaves to Southern slaveholders, and displayed an apathy for abolition.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gigantino|first=James J.|last2=|first2=|last3=|date=|title=TRADING IN JERSEY SOULS:|url=|journal=Pennsylvania History: A Journal of Mid-Atlantic Studies|volume=77|issue=3|pages=282|doi=10.5325/pennhistory.77.3.0281|via=}}</ref> He stated that about one quarter of New Jersey's African American population was forced into labor during the 1830s. Improper information regarding who was free led to it appearing as though slavery decreased more rapidly than it actually did.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gigantino|first1=James|title=The Whole North Is Not Abolitionized|website=Academic Search Complete}}</ref>
==The Civil War== A total of 2,909 [[United States Colored Troops]] from New Jersey served in the Union Army. Because of the state's long-term apprenticeship requirements, at the close of the [[American Civil War]], some African Americans in New Jersey remained in bondage. It was not until the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] was passed in 1865 that the last 16 slaves in the state were freed.<ref name="autogenerated2007"/><ref>According to Snell, James P. ''History of Sussex and Warren Counties, New Jersey, With Illustrations and Biographical Sketches of Its Prominent Men and Pioneers''. (Philadelphia: Everts & Peck, 1881). No ISBN (Pre-1964). Note: Several families in northwestern New Jersey (Sussex County) had slaves who, while legally "freed" by their owners, refused to leave their former masters.</ref>
In the 1860 census, free colored persons in New Jersey numbered 25,318, about 4% of the state's population of 672,035. By 1870 the number had increased to 30,658, but they constituted a smaller percentage of the total population because of the high rate of European immigration. Overall, New Jersey's population had increased to 906,096, with nearly 200,000 European immigrants.<ref>[http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/histcensus/php/state.php Historical Census Browser, 1860 and 1870 censuses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823030234/http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/histcensus/php/state.php |date=2007-08-23 }}. Accessed 28 Oct 2007</ref>
New Jersey was slow to abolish slavery and reluctant to pass the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|13th Amendment]],<ref name="shakir"/> which it did in January 1866. Some of its industries, such as shoes and clothing, had strong markets in the South supplying planters for their slaves, which was probably a factor.<ref>New Jersey ratified the 13th Amendment on 23 January 1866, after having rejected the amendment on 16 March 1865. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080203025541/http://www.nps.gov/archive/malu/documents/amend13.htm], published by the Martin Luther King, Jr., National Historic Site Interpretive Staff, National Park Service (no further authorship information available). Accessed 24 January 2007</ref>
On March 31, 1870 [[Thomas Mundy Peterson]] (1824–1904) became the first [[African American]] to [[vote]] in an [[election]] under the just-enacted provisions of the [[Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|15th Amendment]] to the [[United States Constitution]].<ref name=counting>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Perth Amboy Church Is 302 And Counting |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40711FA345E0C768DDDAB0894DF484D81 |quote=The first black man to vote in America, Thomas Mundy Peterson, was a member of St. Peter's and is buried in its graveyard. He voted in the Perth Amboy mayoral election of March 31, 1870, one day after adoption of the 15th Amendment to the United States Constitution. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=February 15, 1987 |accessdate=2010-11-27 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.npl.org/Pages/ProgramsExhibits/Exhibits/aafirsts.html|title=African-American Firsts Remembered - Newark Public Library|website=Npl.org|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref>
In 1875, "Jack" Jackson, who was described as the last slave in New Jersey,<ref>{{cite web|title=Obituary Index 1874 -1882 |url=http://www.warrenlib.com/warrenlib/local_history/apollovol2.pdf |work=Belvidere Apollo/Intelligencer |accessdate=3 October 2010 |page=116 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203182055/http://warrenlib.com/warrenlib/local_history/apollovol2.pdf |archivedate=3 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> died at the age of 87 on the Smith family farm at [[Secaucus, New Jersey|Secaucus]]. In 1820, Abel Smith had [[Manumission|manumitted]] his slaves, but Jackson refused freedom and remained on the family estate until his death. By the will of the late Abel Smith, Jackson was interred in the [[Abel I. Smith Burial Ground|family burial ground]].<ref>{{cite news|title="Jack" Jackson..|url=http://njsuttonfamily.org/Newspaper/jan1875.htm|accessdate=28 September 2010|newspaper=Hunterdon County Democrat|date=November 30, 1875|location=XXXVIII|page=13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008205048/http://njsuttonfamily.org/Newspaper/jan1875.htm|archivedate=8 October 2010|df=}}</ref>
==Apology== In 2008, the [[New Jersey Legislature]] acknowledged the state's role in the history of slavery in the United States.<ref name="Assembly Concurrent Resolution 230">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Assembly Concurrent Resolution 230 | work = | publisher = [[New Jersey Legislature]] | date = | url = http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2006/bills/acr/270_i1.pdf | doi = | accessdate = | quote = }}</ref><ref name="Peters">{{Cite news | last = Peters | first = Jeremy | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = A Slavery Apology, but Debate Continues | newspaper = The New York Times | pages = | year = | date = January 13, 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/13slaverynj.html?_r=1&scp=6&sq=Vanderbilt&oref=slogin | accessdate = 2011-03-28 | quote = | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref>
{{quote|The Legislature of the State of New Jersey expresses its profound regret for the State's role in slavery and apologizes for the wrongs inflicted by slavery and its after effects in the United States of America; expresses its deepest sympathies and solemn regrets to those who were enslaved and the descendants of those slaves, who were deprived of life, human dignity, and the constitutional protections accorded all citizens of the United States; and we encourage all citizens to remember and teach their children about the history of slavery, Jim Crow laws, and modern day slavery, to ensure that these tragedies will neither be forgotten nor repeated.}}
