revision.text:
'''Yichus''' (יִחוּס), a [[Hebrew]]-based [[Yiddish]] word for [[family tree]] or [[genealogy]], to those who take it seriously, is the [[gatekeeper]] to considering potential marriage partners.
Colloquially it refers to the chain of origin for a statement, creative work or object.<ref>Talk:Midrash (timestamped 17:19, 15 May 2007), QUOTE: If the original source has "yichus" (i.e., Jewish Encyclopedia or Brittanica) ...</ref>
==Etymology== The biblical spelling used in Nech. 7:5 סֵפֶר הַיַּחַשׂ (Book of Lineage)<ref>capitalized ''here'' by Artscroll, but not for the directive לְהִתְיַחֵשׂ, "trace your lineage"</ref> differs in the last letter, compared to both Yiddish and modern Hebrew (יִחוּס, sometimes ייחוס).
Although the word '''yichus''' originated in Hebrew<ref name=Tweb>{{cite web |url=https://www.torchweb.org/torah_detail.php?id=158 |title=Parshas Bamidbar (5771) - Got Yichus?}}</ref><ref>Nechemia,7:5</ref>, the term is generally accepted as a Yiddish word that has flowed into Modern English.
The Anglicized word has been transliterated as * Yichus<ref>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/09/nyregion/dina-abramowicz-90-librarian-and-yiddish-expert-dies.html |date=9 April 2000 |title=Dina Abramowicz, 90, Librarian and Yiddish Expert, Dies}}</ref> * Yikhes<ref name=YIVOencyc>{{cite web |url=http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/article.aspx/Yikhes |title=Yivo Encyclopedia - Yikhes}}</ref><ref>Ironically, it was in the Obituary of a [[YIVO]] expert who spelled it ''Yikhes'' that the NY Times spelled it ''Yichus''.</ref> * Yiches<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewish-languages.org/jewish-english-lexicon/words/618 |title=Jewish English Lexicon}}</ref> * Yikhus<ref>{{cite web |url=http://digitool.library.mcgill.ca/R/?func=dbin-jump-full&object_id=27940&local_base=GEN01-MCG02 |title=Yikhus and the early Hasidic movement |last1=Dynner |first1=Glenn |last2=Hundert |first2=Gershon |website=McGill University}}</ref>
==In Judaism== Despite the fact that being Jewish from birth is universally accepted based on the religion of the mother<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wordnik.com/words/yichus |title=Yichus - definition and meaning - Wordnik}}</ref>, that same universally accepted definition says "(the tribal affiliation, tradition, customs and nusach of prayer) are determined by the Jewish father." To the obvious question<ref>what if the father isn't Jewish</ref> there is the question of why "Rabbah bar Bar Chanah"<ref>A sage in the Talmud. "Bar" means son of. "bar Bar" means son of son of. Chanah is a feminine name.</ref> and the matter of the Blasphemer, Lev. 24:10-23, not accredited to the tribe of Dan.
As far back as the [[Talmud|Talmudic]] era, being son-in-law to someone widely respected was valued.<ref>Gittin,31b,re being son-in-law of the Reish GaLuSa, the Exilarch.</ref> Subsequently, even the ''Yichus'' of being son-in-law to the son-in-law and similar lineage links were on one side, versus "meritocratic leadership based on scholarship" on the other, in the areas of "the arrangement of marriages and determination of hierarchical social distinctions."<ref name=YIVOencyc/>
There were those who, for the above<ref>meritocracy</ref> and other reasons, devalued or hid it: * Dem gonefs yikhes (The Thief's Genealogy) - a song<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kkbox.com/sg/en/song/UIR00MMYPCHZ-zNjZ-zNj0XL-index.html |title=Mark Glanville - Dem gonefs yikhes (The Thief's {{sic|Gene|ology|hide=y}})}}</ref> * "In Lithuania some Jewish families hid their Yikhus (lineage)"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cjh.org/pdfs/Rabbis.pdf |title=Rabbinical Genealogy |website=Center for Jewish History}}</ref>
===Yichus book=== The [[family tree]]s, or pedigree charts, of Jewish families, listing [[genealogy]] and family history records, have been identified with several names, among which are: * Yichus book<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aishdas.org/avodah/vol04/v04n263.shtml |title=Registry of "Who is a Jew" Realpolitik |date=January 2000 |website=aishdas.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://daattorah.blogspot.com/2013/11/weiss-dodelson-gital-face-of-agunot.html |title=Issues of Jewish Identity}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://polishjews.yivoarchives.org/archive/?p=collections/controlcard&id=21384 |title=a "golden book" of "Jewish yikhes" - from an archive about Jewish life in Poland |website=YIVO Archives}}</ref> * Yichus brief<ref>{{cite web |url=https://davidbaisrebeinu.com/2013/09/29/margolios-family-yichus-brief |title=Margolios Family Yichus Brief |website=davidbaisrebeinu.com}}</ref> * Yichus record<ref name=MetzG>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=Israel National News |date= June 22, 2004 |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/64446 |title=MK Porush: Approval of Civil Marriages Spells Disaster}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://daattorah.blogspot.de/2009/12/r-metzger-deviates-from-chareidi-view.html |title=R'Metzger deviates from chareidi view}}</ref>
To help a child trace lineage, some families would write a "Yichus book"<ref name=Margolis>{{cite book |title=Smart Jews: The Construction of the Image of Jewish Superior Intelligence |last1=Gilman |first=Sander L. |date=1997 |publisher=Doubleday |isbn=9780803270695 |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0803270690}}</ref>
The focus of a Yichus brief (letter of relationship)<ref name=Skirb>{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/stream/henryfskirballf001/henryfskirballf001_djvu.txt |title=From the Henry F. Skirball Collection: Some Recollections and Reflections |website=archive.org}}</ref> is not as extensive as a Yichus Book<ref>Sefer HaYichus, singular, or Sefer HaYichusim, plural - on the word Yichus.</ref><ref name=Skirb/><ref>"... drawn up about 15 years ago for one of our relatives. The letter dealt with the ancestors of ..."</ref> whereas a Yichus book or Yichus record/"sefer yuchsin"/registry<ref name=MetzG/> is community-oriented.
Some families also kept a separate "Register of Circumcisions"<ref name=Margolis/>.
==Family name== For various reasons, Last names<ref>written in some cultures "last" hence the terminology</ref>/family names were changed, and sometimes reverted<ref name=Margolis/>. Hence certain family names, such as Cohen, are not as strongly indicative of being a [[Kohen]] as [[Katz (surname)|Katz]].
==Family links== ===Mechutan=== Being the '''[[Yiddish words used in English#M|Mechutan]]'''<ref>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Yeshiva World |url=https://www.theyeshivaworld.com/coffeeroom/topic/how-do-you-say-mechutanim-in-english |title=How do you say Mechutanim in English}} "(grammatically formed in Binyan Pu-al, which is the passive form of Binyan Pea-el and pronounced with a sefardic tuf,not suf)"</ref> of someone important is sometimes important enough to include in a wedding invitation and in giving other credentials.<ref>{{cite web |title=Video: Rav Yisroel Brog: How I Found My Mechutan |date=January 11, 2013 |url=http://matzav.com/video-rav-yisroel-brog-how-i-found-my-mechutan}} "Rav Yisroel Brog is the beloved and brilliant rosh yeshiva of Yeshiva Tiferes Avigdor in Cleveland, Ohio. Rav Brog is... (link to Rav Avigdor Miller, ZTL)</ref> ::ex. "When he was 20 years old, he married the daughter of the [[Vilna]] [[Dayan (rabbinic judge)|Dayan]], who was the son-in-law of ..."<ref>{{cite magazine |magazine=Pirchei weekly |date=May 5, 2018 |page=4 |title=R'[[Chaim Ozer Grodzinski]] |publisher=[[Agudas Yisroel of America]]}}</ref>
Although primarily used for same generation relatives, it can be used beyond that generation.<ref>Ex. That man is a Mechutan to me - his grandson is married to my grand-daughter.</ref>
